pros: The teams are incredible to work with

review_title: Fun and inspiring place to work

review_title: Lovely people but typical arts/charity flaws

Creative environment
Passionate staff/colleagues
Hugely varied arts programme
Amazing historic central London location

Shortage of resources due to cutbacks to arts funding
Low pay (although similar to other arts organisations, museums etc)
Work can be very intense. busy and high pressure
Limited professional deveopment opportunities

review_title: A genuinely wonderful brand and compant

cons: Planning and projects be more joined-up as a whole - the Hayward, QEH, Royal Festival Hall. Are a charity so salaries aren't amazing, but you know you're doing good and that balances it.

pros:
Great institution

pros: Great location, lovely team, charity, have the right views, support everyone

- Fun and creative team to work with.
- Good hours if you are in an admin job.

pros: Good team and well paid

job_title: Visitor Experience Host in London, England

cons: I would say the fact that I dont work there anymore.

pros: great colleagues, good managers and training
cons: no real cons, great place to work

job_title: Ticketing and Membership Assistant in London, England
pros: flexbile, great team, fun, diverse
cons: evening and weekend work, large organisation

pros: Wonderful staff who are committed and hard working. Fun environment and lots of opportunities to see extraordinary events. Everyone is lovely from the hosts and ABM right up to the creative director and head of music.
cons: Awful chief executive with no real arts background but is very keen to be involved in artistic and always promoting their awful chick flick book. Not respected at all although I wonder if they care. They are damaging the work culture and turning it into a toxic environment. There’s been a mass exodus of staff and it’s down to the chief executive and how they treat staff. They fall asleep in meetings, are rude to lower level staff & gets names of teams wrong in all staff meetings and is very very arrogant. They have a fundamental lack of understanding of SC values

review_title: Creative but some issues around staff wellbeing and burnout during my time.
pros: Creative Environment, Space to learn, Big Ambitions for sometimes untenable budgets
cons: Shifting priorities, too large a programme for staff resource and budget. A busy frenetic venue, creative but a place to be careful about workload and department.

pros: Free tickets to the Hayward Gallery and the occasional free tickets in a raffle. Shop floor team are the only good thing about this job - they’re all brilliant people.
cons: Management, no training, no benefits, no progression, you get paid the worst out of all SB employees, shop floor team aren’t regarded very highly in other departments within the company, shop floor team are blamed for poor sales, no praise from management, long hours on your feet and breaks often being forgotten about, holiday is extremely difficult to take, all aspects of the holiday system and rota system are horribly organised and sometimes you don’t know when you’re working until less than a week before the shift starts, etc.

pros: Great place to work because of the ground level staff.
cons: Head of departments are political. won't let you go further or promote. prefers external hires 90% time. no trust within the employees. too much gossip

pros: My team are amazing and would not be continuing to work here if it wasn't for the support they give me on a daily basis.
cons: The management of the department is absolutely terrible.  I worry if I have been paid correctly every month, as I have worked over bank holidays in the past where the extra time has not been paid to me. The head of the department is very unprofessional with staff. I work in a customer environment and I have been belittled directly in front of customers by being shouted at. Staff are always worried about approaching management about concerns that they have and HR are 'friends' with the management team of my department and are therefore often unhelpful when resolving requests. Working environments are sometimes pretty bad (no air conditioning in certain places in the summer, making it impossible to work without regular breaks which we often don't receive) You are not praised for going above and beyond in your role or if you take on additional hours when someone calls in sick or temporary members of staff don't turn up for shifts. Calling in sick is difficult and there have been times where I have called for hours without any response. This would be a lovely place to work but team members are always worried about doing something 'wrong' and don't get the support they need and therefore it makes for a horrible environment to work in. Rotas are also poor and there have been times in the past where we have not been given rotas until less than a week before we are due to work - makes it impossible if you want to plan your life around other commitments which many of us have.

review_title: Too many process bottlenecks where very senior staff don't trust or empower those below them to make decisions.
pros: Great location. Inspiring art projects.
cons: No trust from senior managers which creates an infantilised staff. Such an amazing talented team could do so much more good stuff if given the chance.

pros: Southbank Centre is an exciting place to work, employees are mostly extremely passionate about what they do and are lovely people.
cons: Rates of pay are lower than elsewhere for the role I did. "Lean" teams so always lots of work to do (although many employees do manage to leave on time every day)

job_title: Visitor Experience Host in London, England
pros: Worked as a visitor experience host around my studies - very friendly lot, got to watch some amazing shows during my time there!
cons: A lot of people scrambling for not many hours. Felt like we were competing for shifts at points
